div1.p: Carter describes the ailments of his patients to his mother.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, June 20, 1880
div1.p:
The mail must be in between Cairo &
Beneblana, as I most certainly wrote last week & your Sun-
day letter reached me Friday, (or Thursday) morning. I've had
an accidental week, Sunday evening I went down to a
boat to dress a couple of broken ribs; you remember how hot
it was & I, by myself except for my patient, in the
close hold of the vessel I nearly melted. Saturday I got
a small boy (9 years with a broken thigh &, Saturday even-
ing another with a fish hook in his hand (took chloro-
form & had it cut out) Monday night was called up
to see a Sunstroke & a little later to see a man
who had fallen 65 feet, from the top of a flag pole. &
who wlas terribly injured. Also a stab wound on Wednes-
day. Most of my cases are rather bad ones now. I've one
boy of 19, Frakes, who has what is called here “Conges-
tion of the stomach & bowels.” A kind of cholera morbis that
lasts from 3 days to a week & that kills if not attended
to. Being put on light diet the day he entered (Friday) he
got up at night & stole all the fruit he could find about a
peck, (bananas, oranges & apples). Well, yesterday he nearly died &
I did work over him, & so last night. This morning he was a
great deal better, & after teasing for pie, etc & being denied
I found him when I went up at noon to see him, in the
orchard eating green apples, he said he had eaten only 4 or 5, I
hope so. He is a good deal worse now, I had explained to him what
was my reason for keeping him on light diet & it is hard to un-
derstand how a man can be so silly. If he dies, I will no
way consider myself to blame

About the man who fell from the flag pole, he
was about as badly broken up as any one I ever saw, that to have
his limbs broken. 2 ribs (or one) were seen in his lungs (4 being broken)
& a bad scalp wound, which now has dead bone in it, but I
think he will recover, he certainly is doing well so far: So is my
boy with the leg - this is a private case. Very tired of lying in bed
but the leg is in good position & he has no pain. Tell Ed it is set
by extension (4 lbs of shot) & binders board, & I will put him
in an “Anterior Suspensory Splint” as soon as may be, also
that I don't like plaster. I've seen 3 infected fractures with
it & none where it was not used.

Ed is at home now, isn't he? & so is May. I am so glad that you
have them. It is a good thing that Ed will stay at North River
this summer. I'm glad of it for my reasons & especially for your
sake, I wish I could be there also & if I can get away in the fall I'll
do so. It doesn't seem so long since I was at home & I've changed very
little, but I'd have such a lot to tell. It would do me a great
deal of good too to be with my own people again. But, if I
ain't at home, I feel as if I wasn't much separated from you;
as if I was one destined to go out & make something to help
start the rest. What time will Chas, go to college? in a-
bout a fortnight! I'm glad that he & Ed will overlap in
their times. Aren't you glad to have May at home again? How
is her health? How does quinine disagree with Emma? It is quite
fashionable to say so out here. Every negro man, says he can't take
quinine, it “affects” him. I give him the pills or the solu-
tion & say nothing about it & he takes it & gets well,

This is the end of the Fiscal year & I've no end of work to do, began
on it yesterday, I can do as much work as the next man

You used to say He'll never write more than one page & one
line. I can't say all I want on 4 pages but my time runs out.
